How To Build a Twitter Text Generating AI Bot with GPT-2

all_paragraphs: Imagine collaborating on a Medium article with an artificial intelligence that has read every single word you’ve ever written — a language model that learned from your posts, essays, dictated notes, early drafts, scanned diary entries, research files, favorite quotes, and every other scrap of thought that makes your writing unique.

Your AI writing partner could deliver a smart critique of your essay and make suggestions about how to improve your argument. It could surface inspiring quotes you could include and remind you to mention an odd thought you saved on your smartphone while waiting in line at the DMV three years ago.
Artificial intelligence won’t replace writers. It will enhance your writing process, giving you a customized reader and editor precisely calibrated to work improve your style, voice, and themes.
I can’t wait for this world to arrive. I taught myself enough coding to generate fiction with AI tools, but at my heart, I’m a journalist — a nonfiction storyteller.
I wanted to see how AI could help my nonfiction writing right now. So using the super-powered language model GPT-2, I trained an AI to generate movie reviews for Film Threat magazine.
This short-form nonfiction experiment gave me an early glimpse of future writing tools we will use someday while writing for Medium.

When OpenAI unveiled the GPT-2 language model last year, the creators worried about how bad actors could abuse the tool. The company slowly released different strength versions of its model, watching carefully for abuses of GPT-2’s power.
They worried that it could be used to:
“Generate misleading news articlesImpersonate others onlineAutomate the production of abusive or faked content to post on social mediaAutomate the production of spam/phishing content”

One year later, GPT-2 is fully available for civilians to use, powering amazing games, creative writing experiments, and recipe generation. So far, we haven’t seen the large-scale generation of fake nonfiction.

I believe the most interesting (and potentially dangerous) applications of GPT-2 will come from short-form nonfiction. Amazon reviews, book blurbs, and movie reactions already consume so much of our online attention, sometimes swaying people’s opinions about a product or work of art.

When starting this project, I chose movie reviews for my base materials, because a vast collection of user-generated reviews exist online — some of it collected in publicly available datasets. You could easily build a dataset with book reviews, news articles, sports coverage, or your nonfiction writing.

Working with the editorial team at Film Threat last year, I started developing an AI capable of writing movie reviews. We’ve published a few pieces together, and I’d like to share how we trained our model.
The project began simply, before I had access to tools capable of fine-tuning GPT-2. Even so, the regular model worked pretty well for film criticism.

In the first article at Film Threat, I started by generating moving reviews with Talk To Transformer. This website gives you instant access to GPT-2. All you have to do is enter a question about a movie, and click “Complete.” No coding necessary!
I asked GPT-2 a leading question: “Who was the first artificial intelligence to write movie reviews?” We got this most excellent computer-generated response (completely unedited):
GPT-2 gave me the name of our computer-generated film critic. Using that name and some leading questions, I generated enough material for an entire Film Threat article with this simple interface.

But I wanted to make something more sophisticated. For the next article, I upgraded Artificial Intelligence Reviewer — making a language model capable of churning out endless movie reviews. On demand.

Using a machine learning technique called “fine-tuning,” I retrained the GPT-2 language model that powered Artificial Intelligence Reviewer with a MASSIVE dataset of movie criticism. I fed the hungry bot a huge movie review dataset, giving AI Reviewer a whole new vocabulary for critiquing movies.
You can read the results in my second Film Threat article, matching readers’ favorite movies with a computer-generated review.
Here’s how I trained the AI for Film Threat…

First, you need to find samples of your nonfiction — book reviews, Amazon user feedback, footnotes, Twitter posts, or whatever short-form nonfiction you want to computer generate. There are lots of movie review datasets online. Here’s one dataset I found at the Stanford AI Lab website:

“This is a dataset for binary sentiment classification containing substantially more data than previous benchmark datasets. We provide a set of 25,000 highly polar movie reviews for training, and 25,000 for testing.”

Fine-tuning both my language models took a few days. Max Woolf created an amazing Google Colab notebook that makes this step painless and free. I used the medium-sized 355M version of GPT-2 because it was large enough to handle my data set but small enough to run on Google Colab’s cloud servers. I trained my model 23,000 steps each.
I broke the training sequence into three smaller sections, because Google Colab won’t run more than 12,000 steps.

Once my language model was trained, I began generating hundreds of generic movie reviews. These were interesting, but a little unfocused. For each run, I set a length of 200 characters, the temperature at .7, and the output at 10 samples.
The real magic happens when you start to load new prefixes into the model. It can be as simple as naming a movie. Here’s the first test I ever tried:
We immediately tested our supercharged AI on a review of Star Wars. In a few seconds, Artificial Intelligence Reviewer had generated a few zinging take-downs like this:
But then, AI Reviewer followed up with gushing reviews of Star Wars, like this:

I kept hitting “run,” over and over again, until I filled up a blank document with thousands of reviews. It took lots of human reading to find the best reviews out of this potentially endless stream of Star Wars reviews.

Once I had some interesting material focused on single title prefixes, I started focusing on different directors and actors to get more specific film criticism. THIS is where things start to get interesting, when you start playing with the limits of the model.
That prefix got us a crazy review of one of my favorite foreign language films of 2019. That final mash-up of movie genres still makes me laugh.
I also introduced some new verbs like “win” and “lose” into my prefixes, as we neared award season.
Those prefixes will get you a whole load of Oscar predictions! Like this:

Nonfiction generated by artificial intelligence will always require a human editor. To find a single good movie review, I had to read hundreds and hundreds of pages of boring, strange or even normal-sounding prose. It’s a lot of work. But I never said AI would replace writers. It will just help us write better.

Just like I could build Artificial Intelligence Reviewer to make hilarious and strange movie criticism, I could train my GPT-2 writing partner with all my collected digital writing. I have at least a decade of digital text, including notes, research, drafts, and highlights from my eBook reading. I could make a true writing partner, reshaping and refreshing my thoughts whenever I need a creative boost.

Max Woolf’s work has always inspired me, and his recent essay, “How To Build a Twitter Text Generating AI Bot with GPT-2,” shows us how these language models trained on short-form nonfiction can live a whole life online.
He also offered some caution about the size of your dataset. If you want to generate unique text with a smaller dataset, you’ll need to follow this advice:

Note that without a lot of tweets, the model might easily overfit and output existing tweets verbatim; if that’s the case, you may want to train for fewer steps (e.g. 200–500). Additionally, I recommend only using the 124M “small” and 355M “medium” GPT-2 models; larger GPT-2 models finetune poorly on small text documents and low amounts of input data.

With that tool alone, you could create a Twitter bot to post for you or create a new bot that posts about your favorite topics. Who knows what other tools will be available by the end of the year as GPT-2 and other language models get placed inside new frameworks?
Author and creative programmer Darius Kazemi once compared these language model advancements to the early days of Photoshop for graphic artists:

“If you’re interested in the future of writing, this is definitely worth keeping an eye on. It’s like being a photographer at the advent of Photoshop, because it could be game-changing for the medium.”
Someday, I hope, these tools will help us craft new stories we can’t even imagine yet.
